title: One in ten drivers feel safer on 'smart' motorways, finds new survey
text:
Smart motorways don't feel as safe as traditional motorways - that the verdict of 15,000 drivers who have provided yet another damning verdict on the controversial modern roads.

Just one in 10 drivers polled by the AA said they feel safer on an All Lane Running smart motorway compared to a traditional motorway, as pressure mounts on the Government to re-think the redevelopment on hundreds of miles of fast-moving roads at the cost of billions of pounds.

This follows several deaths on routes that have already been converted to smart motorways, with new data showing the removal of a hard shoulder is putting drivers at unnecessary risk.

Smart motorway concerns mount: A new poll of 15,000 drivers has found that just 1 in 10 feel safer on All Lane Running routes than traditional motorways with hard shoulders

Edmund King, president at the AA, warned ministers: 'Before any further smart motorway schemes begin, we need an urgent and independent review into the safety of existing schemes.'

Recent figures revealed that 19,316 motorists suffered the horror of breaking down in a smart motorway live lane in 2017 and 2018, which is around 26 drivers a day.

The shocking numbers were confirmed by Highways England chief executive Jim O'Sullivan to the Transport Committee earlier this month after MPs had written to him regarding fears over the safety of smart motorways.

It appears these concerns are shared by the majority of drivers.

While there are three different types - Controlled Motorway, Dynamic Hard Shoulder and All Lane Running - it's the latter that is causing the most concern.

The AA's survey found that seven out of 10 motorists believed that ALR schemes felt more dangerous than a motorway with a permanent hard shoulder.

These routes convert what used to be a hard shoulder into a live lane to improve traffic flow and reduce congestion.

In the place of hard shoulders are Emergency Refuge Areas, which are short lay-bys that are just a matter of metres long and only appear on existing ALR routes every 1.5 miles.

Cost revealed by the Government back in 2016 estimated that it would take £1.25billion to convert eight sections along parts of the M1, M3, M6 and M25 into ALR motorways.

Highways England projections for ALR conversions on eight sections of motorway amounted to over £1.25billion

All-lane-running smart motorways have an emergency refuge area for vehicles that have broken down or crashed every 1.5 miles. There have been campaigns for more to be added

O'Sullivan also admitted in his letter that 71 per cent of stops made in the lay-bys in the previous two years were not emergency-related, raising fears that drivers with genuine vehicle issues might be unable to stop as these short pull-off areas are full.

The 3 types of smart motorway 1. Controlled Motorway Multiple lanes, variable speed limits and a hard shoulder for emergencies only. 2. Dynamic Hard Shoulder Variable speed limits and a hard shoulder that can be turned into a fourth lane when needed. Drivers are told via electric overhead signs to use the hard shoulder during peak hours. 3. All-Lanes Running Variable speed limits and a permanent fourth lane instead of a hard shoulder. Emergency refuge areas currently can be found every 2.5km (1.55 miles) though will be shortened from April 2020.

Intervals between the lay-bys are due to be reduced to a maximum of one mile under new rules put in place by Highways England earlier this year, though will only apply to converted motorways from April next year.

While these refuge lay-bys will appear more often, the AA poll found that drivers want them to occur more frequently.

Almost two thirds of the panel said they should appear every half a mile, according to the survey findings.

Serious safety concerns have been mounting over ALR routes following a string of five deaths along the same stretch of the M1.

Earlier this month a coroner warned that smart motorways were 'putting lives at risk' after an eight-year-old boy was killed when a lorry hit his grandfather's stranded car on the M6 last year.

Dev Naran, from Leicestershire, died instantly when the Toyota Yaris he was in - which was stopped in lane one, previously a hard shoulder but now a live lane - was hit at 56mph in May 2018.

The news comes as the new Secretary of State for Transport, Grant Shapps, will give evidence before the Transport Select Committee today to outline his priorities for the role.

A spate of deaths on smart motorways have heightened concerns for their safety. The AA says there needs to be an urgent review of the scheme

Edmund King added: 'We believe the Secretary of State should now announce a review into the safety of All Lane Running Schemes.

'Unfortunately we have already seen fatalities where vehicles have been left in vulnerable positions in live lanes.

'Previous research has shown that if Stopped Vehicle Detection is not in place it takes an average of 17 minutes to spot a stationary vehicle in a live lane.

'Our new study shows that public trust on removing the hard shoulder has pretty much evaporated.'
